timeline.message: Add files for longleaf registration job and tests
Add longleaf registration job to deposit supervisor list
Call longleaf script to register files
Add longleaf log file path and switch to md5 checksums

timeline.bodyText: you might need to bump this up out of the FileObject block since Units, Collections, Folders, Works and Files can all have MODS descriptions.
timeline.author: bbpennel

replies.bodyText:
We would also want to register manifest files from deposit records (they use storageUri as well), and fits extracts for FileObjects (fitsStorageUri), and PREMIS logs for everything. The premis logs don't get their location recorded in the deposit model at the moment, it might make sense to start recording that in there, or to have the PremisLogger class have a way to get the location of the log back. I am happy to add a way to get the PREMIS file location if that'd be helpful.
You might actually just want to seek the uris that are available rather than checking object types now that I think about it.
replies.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText: Minor suggestion, but it would probably be best to parse the value into a URI (URI.create(string) should be fine here) which gets passed into registerFile. Then in register file, you can do Paths.get(storageUri) and then I believe toString on the path gives you the file path without the scheme. I know its more steps, but lets you use the standard java mechanisms for working with uris/paths and gets things a little more ready for the future in which we may not have file uris in all cases.
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText: Can remove this or replace it with a log.debug
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText:
Having a separate log file is a good idea. I would suggest using the logging framework to make it a bit easier to control though. You can add something like:
private static final Logger longleafLog = LoggerFactory.getLogger("longleaf");
to the top of this file, and then call longleafLog.info or whatever in order to write to it. I think it will automatically send the output to the root logger if you don't configure it. But then we can also update the logback config file for dev and test to send it to a particular path, rather than having to inject a property into this job.
Its also possible to redirect info versus error statements to different log files, which may be helpful in production-like environments.
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText: Use try (BufferedReader in = new BufferedReader(...)) { syntax so you don't need to worry about closing the reader. Otherwise you'll need to add the close into a finally block here.
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText:
this approach for test files works too, but wanted to mentioned that junit has a built in mechanism for making files and directories that get cleaned up:
https://github.com/UNC-Libraries/Carolina-Digital-Repository/blob/fcrepo4/persistence/src/test/java/edu/unc/lib/dl/persist/services/storage/StorageLocationManagerImplTest.java#L73
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText:
There are some built in java utilities for setting file permissions these days:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/664432/how-do-i-programmatically-change-file-permissions
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText: i think you can skip the force flag here since that is just needed for registering files that have previous been registered, which shouldn't be the case for ingest.
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText: You can do FileUtils.readFileToString(file, encoding) as a shortcut for reading the output file.
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText: one minor suggestion, i'd recommend using null to represent the absence of something rather than an empty string

timeline.bodyText: Just to make sure i understand this test, its to verify that a file that is in the deposit but has no storage uri is not registered to longleaf?
timeline.author: bbpennel

replies.bodyText: Yes, I think this case probably would never happen since anything that gets this far would have a storageUri value.  I can remove it if it seems unnecessary.
replies.author: smithjp

replies.bodyText: No i think this is fine, just wanted to make sure i understood
replies.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText:
add a StandardCharsets.UTF-8 to each of these readFileToString, my IDE gets grumpy without it :)
Also, just a suggestion, but if you hold onto the File object representation of the outputPath when its first created you could save a bit of effort on instantiating new file objects.
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText: These tests look good. Could you add one more which verifies things work properly if the same object has multiple types of file? So mods, fits, premis, original file, or some subset of them.
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.author: bbpennel

replies.bodyText: Not sure if you saw this comment
replies.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText:
something weird is happening here with the checksums. on my vm it is generating records with the following metadata:
  checksums:
    "'md5": 6da75e45469b88aeaa5415e574c385e2'

note the extra single quotes. To produce the same affect on the commandline i had to double quote the param:
 sudo scl enable rh-ruby24 -- longleaf register -c /opt/longleaf/config.yml -f /opt/data/primary_storage/37/e8/fa/f5/37e8faf5-2a33-4a8c-b96b-0a19deadc5fe/datafs/original_file --checksums "'md5:6da75e45469b88aeaa5415e574c385e2'" --force
maybe exec is wrapping the value? could also try double quotes
timeline.author: bbpennel
